subject: RE: Writing code (was RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency  Hierarchy)
msgSnippet: ... distorted what we have written. J.B. you ve said this to me more than once. Hopefully it is clear that I am trying, but there is a lot to read & mistakes
messageBody:
J.B. wrote:

> Adam, please read more closely. This is the second time that you have
distorted what we have written.

J.B. you've said this to me more than once. Hopefully it is clear that I am
trying, but there is a lot to read & mistakes will be made. I feel you've
distorted what I've said a number of times, I think it is an unfortunate
aspect of communication, on both our parts. Hopefully with us both trying we
are getting past that.

> Your idea is not unwelcome. I have stated -- a few times -- that what you
propose (the ability to
> manage dependencies of the sort you describe) is a good idea and would
likely be welcome to others. All > I have said is that I do not believe it
belongs at the core of JUnit.

You never communicated that to me. Your e-mails made me think otherwise.
Comments like:

"Get this straight: TEST CASE DEPENDENCY IS EVIL."

... kinda made me think otherwise.

> As for hoping that the JUnit team will assist you, I guess you don't know
the JUnit team very well. Kent > and Erich are nice folks, but they are not
active contributors to JUnit these days. Just look at the gulfs > in time
between releases to convince yourself. Kent and Erich are not going to jump
on board and help
> you with this. They don't have the time or energy. The real activity is in
add-on projects like
> JUnit-addons.

Don't know them? Never heard of them, sorry and all. That is no insult, and
no measure of my gratitude for what they've produced and how I and the
community have benefited from their work. I also happen to have always been
impressed w/ the internals/design concepts in junit. That all said, none of
this is relevant .... I wasn't talking to them, I was talking to this list.

OSS is (IMHO) a facet of the current community. I don't want help, I wanted
to share/discuss a thought. If at the end of the day I write some code, then
great, but I feel the idea needs better pressure testing & don't wish to
rush to code.

> <snip/>
> A good solution to your problem is the second: a custom test runner with a
dependency graph collector/analyzer.

Ok, so have we moved off "I can do it with suites". I agree, a runner is
also needed. I also think I need a way (on the TestCase) to express
dependency. But, if I write collector plus runner and add to testcase, how
much of the framework have I replicated? How much benefited in my
environment of ant and eclipse? Not much. I also don't want to take the ant
route and do an effective re-write.

> Excuse me: did you expect that we would suspend our lives and help you
write what you need?

Actually, yes. Why not? Folks hack into junit out of love for it, out of a
desire to improve it. If something is a good idea, why not?

> That's not how open source works.

Actually, I feel it is. Convince the development team it is a good idea, and
important, and they (closer to the implementation) are more than likely to
do the work, and should 'cos they know the bigger picture. Well, that is how
I feel if folks come to me for something.

> I didn't see you handing out invitations; but rather asking, "Why don't
you
> people add this to JUnit?" That we don't need, thanks.

Your interpretation, not mine. I said -- is it a good thing for junit, I
never said I'd not try to help write it.


>Yes, I know, I've written for both. I'm hardly going to try to replicate
> all the work for both plugins just to try to get this point over.

> Then I guess you don't need it that badly.

Correct, but is that a measure of the idea, or the hurdle put in it's way?

> You conclude that the community of developers is not open to accepting a
core change.
> The alternate conclusion is that the community of developers does not
believe your particular proposed
> change is a good idea.
> On what basis did you choose your conclusion over the alternative?

From the fact that I only heard your voice, and (perhaps incorrectly, it was
my first posting) I felt that maybe you spoke for the community. Nobody else
was doing so back then. For all I knew you could've been "the original
author". Whatever, the ideas presented on the mailing list give newbies like
me feeling for the community. A community is what it posts...

> When you are ready to accept the possibility that we merely disagree with
you, rather than are
> nefariously blocking your proposal, please come back and discuss this with
us again.

Nice try, but wrong. I am often wrong, numerous times -- and more than I am
right. Honestly, I love it when somebody proves me wrong on something, I
feel I've learned something. But, I can't quit a discussion because it
becomes an argument, I couldn't let this idea die because of distractions.
It didn't get a fair hearing (back then) and I'm glad the rest of the list
has stepped in and opened things up. I was ready to quit, but now am
learning more & benefiting from the comments.

regards

Adam
